array.string: They are archaic humans who lived in France and disappeared about 40000 years ago. What are they called?
There has never been any interbreeding between Neanderthal and Homo sapiens.
They began to immigrate, in great numbers, into the region of modern France around 800 B.C. Who are they?
By the 1st century AD, most Celtic territories had become part of the Roman Empire.
From Gaul they invaded Rome in 390 BC winning the battle of Allia. Who are they?
The Senones who invaded northern Italy and Rome were led by Brennus
He won the Gallic Wars in 51 BC" . What was their name
Caesar's son rose to sole power after defeating his opponents in the last civil war of the Roman Republic.
What was the first name of the city of Paris, founded in 52 B.C?
Lutetia was never conquered by the Romans
What was the name of the first king of the Franks to unite all the Frankish tribes?
Clovis succeeded his father, Childeric I, as a king of Salian Franks in 481
Clovis I becomes king of the Franks.
To which dynasty did Clovis belong?
The Merovingians' long hair distinguished them among the Franks, who commonly cut their hair short.
In 732 he defeats the Muslims at Poitiers, stopping the Arab invasion. Who is he?
Charles Martel belongs to the Merovingian dynasty.
To which dynasty did Charlemagne belong?
He was the first recognized emperor to rule from western Europe since the fall of the Western Roman Empire.
Charlemagne new king of the Franks.
He united the majority of western and central Europe and he was crowned emperor of the Romans in 800. Who is he?
Charlemagne had no son to succeed him.

This treaty signed in August 843 was the first stage in the dissolution of the empire of Charlemagne and foreshadowed the formation of the modern countries of western Europe. What is the name of this treaty?
The treaty, signed in Verdun-sur-Meuse, ended the three-year Carolingian Civil War.
From 1309 to 1376 seven successive popes resided in this French city.
During this same period, a pope had also been appointed in Rome. So there were two popes.
Who won the Hundred Years' War that lasted from 1337–1453?
There was no truce for the duration of the Hundred Years' War.
End of the Hundred Years War.
This King of France was a prodigious patron of the arts, he promoted the emergent French Renaissance by attracting many Italian artists to work for him, including Leonardo da Vinci. Who is he?
Francis I formed a Franco-Ottoman alliance with the Muslim sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, a controversial move for a Christian king at the time.
Francis I crowned king of France.
Henri IV was the first king of what dynasty?
Henry IV never converted to Catholicism
Henri IV crowned king of France.
These French Calvinist Protestants were the victims of the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre. What was their name?
Traditionally, the massacre is believed to have been instigated by Queen Catherine de' Medici, the mother of King Charles IX.
He was known has the Sun King (Le roi Soleil). Who is he?
Louis XIV promulgated the Edict of Nantes, granting the Huguenots, substantial rights.
This French King built the Versailles Palace and moved the seat of his court there. Who is he?
Louis XiV reign lasted 72 years, the longest recorded of any monarch of a sovereign country in history.
In which country was Queen Marie Antoinette born?
She became dauphine of France at age 14 upon her marriage.
The year the French Revolution started by the storming of the Bastille. What year is it?
The Bastille was a political prison seen by the revolutionaries as a symbol of the monarchy's abuse of power.
She was the queen of France and was guillotined during the French Revolution. Who is she?
Before the revolution Marie-Antoinette was liked by the population.
In 1794 he was overthrown, executed and the Reign of Terror ended. Who is he?
Robespierre is best known for his role as a member of the Committee of Public Safety as he signed 542 arrests.
On December 2, 1805, Napoleon won what is considered its greatest victory. What was the name of the battle?
The Battle of Austerlitz is also known as the Battle of the Three Emperors.
What was the most eastern city occupied by Napoleon in September 1812?
After invading Moscow, the French were able to resupply to continue the attack.
On Sunday, 18 June 1815, Napoleon suffered is final defeat. What was the name of the battle?
Waterloo was not Napoleon's last battle, other battles took place before his surrender.
In 1852 Napoleon III is crowned emperor. What was its relation with Napoleon I?
In 1870, after the defeat of the French army at the hands of the Prussians, Napoleon III was made prisoner.

The period between 1871 and 1914 it was characterised by optimism, regional peace, economic prosperity, colonial expansion, and technological, scientific, and cultural innovations. What name is given to this period?
Despite the prosperity, "La Belle Époque" was a time when Europe experienced a decline in its global political power.
What year was the Eiffel Tower inaugurated?
The Eiffel Tower was initially criticized by some of France's leading artists and intellectuals for its design.

In December 1894 a French artillery officer of Jewish descent was falsely convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for communicating French military secrets to the German Embassy in Paris. What was his name?
Despite his exoneration, Dreyfus was never reinstated in the French army.
The French lost more than 400,000 men defending what city against the Germans in World War I?
The battle lasted for 302 days, the longest and one of the most costly in human history.
Although he was considered a war hero after WW1 after WW2, he was convicted of treason. What is his name?
Pétain led the French Army to victory at the nine-month-long Battle of Verdun.
Pétain signs the armistice with Germany
